Looks good +1. Thanks @sekikn .
Thanks for merging!

* manually tested by putting file into encryption zone with `hadoop.security.secure.random.impl=org.apache.hadoop.crypto.random.OpensslSecureRandom` on CentOS 8 (openssl-1.1.1-8.el8.x86_64).
* ran smoke test of hdfs, yarn, mapreduce and kms on CentOS 7 (openssl-1.0.2k-19.el7.x86_64) to check regression on OpenSSL < 1.1.0 env.

```
docker:
        memory_limit: "12g"
        image: "bigtop/puppet:trunk-centos-7"
distro: centos
components: [hdfs, yarn, mapreduce, kms]
enable_local_repo: true
smoke_test_components: [hdfs, yarn, mapreduce, kms]
```
Looks promising. +1. Thanks @iwasakims.
merged. Thanks, @evans-ye.

I'm a +1 to @sekikn.
The rationale here should be if no one volunteer to work on it, we can vote to drop the support and move onward. As discussed previous on mailing list: our strategy is focus on core, user-demanded features instead of supporting many components across many platforms.
So yes. Let's bring this back to mailing list. We should give people who care about PPC the chance to chime in.
@guyuqi could you help to arrange a discussion in bigtop dev list? Thanks!

> @guyuqi could you help to arrange a discussion in bigtop dev list? Thanks!

Yes.
The build or smoke tests would fail if they were running against by original docker images (bigtop/slaves:trunk-ubuntu-16.04).

Run the logstash smoke tests on my local test enviroments:
1. rebuild docker images to add ruby/rake support (bigtop/slaves: yuqi-ubuntu-16.04 )
2.  config_ubuntu-16.04.yaml
```
docker:
        memory_limit: "4g"
        image:  "bigtop/puppet:yuqi-ubuntu-16.04"

repo: "http://repos.bigtop.apache.org/releases/1.4.0/ubuntu/16.04/$(ARCH)"
distro: debian
components: [logstash]

enable_local_repo: true
smoke_test_components: [logstash]
```
The log was posted [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1rZfBOet1GfnVr4FK06j7q9TgCH5xaEPCkJEAiQHT3jw/edit?usp=sharing).

Maybe we can retrigger the CI to rebuild docker images related.

For the modification of this PR is complicated,
How about to: 
1. Submit another PR to just add ruby to bigtop toolchain.
2. Then we could verify this PR smoothly.
What do you think?  @evans-ye

Sure. I think your suggestion is great. Let's work on the ruby in another JIRA and revisit this one.
Thanks!

@leolb-aphp hey, are you fine with the COVID-19 outbreak? I hope you and your family are well!
Do you have the cycles to iterate on this?
Depends on BIGTOP-3327 #631

@evans-ye hey, I am fine. I'm still working, on other things though. We're still interested in this, but I am in charge of security and we succeeded kind of moving Hadoop outside of the security critical perimeter because it's kind of a mess to secure for our use case. I started doing this port on hardware which I do not have anymore because I'm working remotely, so I don't have my test environment easily accessible anymore. And the machine I work on right now runs on the ppc64le architecture, so I assume there's more to fix than just Solr to make things work on ppc64le.
@evans-ye  BIGTOP-3346 created and #632 posted.

> I prefer to have ruby from distro or rvm.

@oflebbe really thanks for your comments.

We do need the ruby-related facilities such as ruby rumtime, rake, gem and bundle to build logstash. 
And for the Arm64 dependency issues, the ruby-2.4 is the latest version that works with logstash. 
But ruby version is 2.0 in Centos 7 and 2.3 in ubuntu16.04.

When leveraging rvm to install ruby, rvm would pull the ruby binaries and spend less time than  compiling ruby directly on x86_64.
But on Arm64, no ruby binaries are available and rvm would also download source code and compile ruby.

IMHO, our Bigtop should support different kind of distros and platforms(x86_64/arm64).
If ruby-2.4 were downloaded and compiled directly , it could guarantee that ruby-related facilities would be properly installed on the various distros and platforms though it may cost extra time just on x86 when building bigtop_toolchain. WDYT? 
Thanks!
Verified with ubuntu-18.04 on both arm and x86. Thanks, @guyuqi
Verified on arm and x86 with bigtop/slaves:ubuntu-18.04. Thanks @guyuqi

I do not get your argument, since the proposed change is to compile ruby for all platforms. I do not prefer to bring software already available for a platform as a native package in a suitable quality. For instance Debian, Ubuntu 18.04

Regarding centos7 we should use https://www.softwarecollections.org/en/scls/rhscl/rh-ruby26/ . This is a redhat provided service for RHEL and Centos and integrates nicely with Centos, AFAIK.

Ubuntu 16.04 should be removed, since it is outdated. We should support 18.04 instead. 

If you find these are not compelling arguments, please go ahead.
Thanks @guyuqi

@guyuqi @oflebbe I think we can leverage Ruby on those platforms which already have ruby that meet the requirement. I'm guessing that most of the user just choose one arch X platform. If we compile our own dependencies, then user much do so in there env, which is not that ideal. Does this make sense?

Just my two cents, how about we only support Logstash on the distros that provides Ruby 2.4+ natively and doesn't on relatively old ones, i.e., CentOS 7, Debian 9 (which provides Ruby 2.3.3) and Ubuntu 16.04?
+1, merged into master. Thanks!

I've already merged #633, so would you rename the new patch in this PR to a name starting with "patch4" to clarify their application order (though it doesn't matter which one is applied first in this case)?
Thanks, @sekikn.
@sekikn Sure. I renamed the added file.
I agree @sekikn . All the platforms you are mentioning should be deprecated and therefore it should be ok to not provide new functionality.

> I agree @sekikn . All the platforms you are mentioning should be deprecated and therefore it should be ok to not provide new functionality.

Yup, it makes sense. Thanks, @oflebbe @sekikn @evans-ye
Thanks @evans-ye !

As disscussion on #632 : 
1. Remove the ruby from bigtog_toolchain.
2. For dependency problem, we still take rvm to install ruby-2.4 to build logstash in `do-component-build`.
3. Do not install ruby native package and run the logstash against the ruby which is provided by distros.
In other words, just support Logstash on the distros that already provides Ruby 2.4+ natively:   ubuntu-18.04, debian-10, centos-8 and fedora-31.

From the disscussion above, this PR would be abandoned. 
For logstash, the ruby native package would not be installed in bigtop_toolchain.
Just support Logstash on the distros that provides Ruby 2.4+ for runtime. (distros: Ubuntu-18.04, Debian-10, Centos-8 and Fedora-31)
The logstash smoke tests in this PR depends on BIGTOP-3343 ( PR #634 ) for docker provisioner support in Ubuntu-18.04 and Debian-10.

For 1. what do you meant by remove ruby? a) remove compile ruby b) remove ruby installation
For 2, seems like we can still move the build env preparation stuffs into bigtop_toolchain? no?

If we still put ruby-installation into Bigtop_toolchain, it would override the ruby package already provided by distros. 
So both remove ruby compiling and ruby installation from Bigtop_toolchain.

So just install ruby in the phase of build `do-component-build`.

For logstash runtime, we could leverage the ruby2.3.8+ which has been already provided by distros.
Then we doesn't support logstash on CentOS-7, Debian-9 ,ubuntu-16.04 which provides ruby < 2.3.8.

As disscussion on dev list, we decide to drop the Zeppelin ppc64le support in the next release.
Do you have any other comments on this PR? @evans-ye @sekikn

Thanks for brought this up. Could you please conclude the voting result on the mailing list so that we spread out an explicitly conclusion to the community? Once that's done we can proceed this one as discussed. You can search over the bigtop mailing list for [RESULT] tag and get to know how to do the tally. Thanks!

        memory_limit: "12g"

distro: centos
components: [hdfs, yarn, mapreduce, tez, hive]
enable_local_repo: true
smoke_test_components: [hive]
```
I am not super familiar with the puppet code but it looks good! Any downside or things that you don't particularly like about the solution?

+1. Thanks!
Thanks, @evans-ye.

@guyuqi I'm new to this world of bigtop/Mpacks.  But It's my definite understanding that Mpacks are supposed to be deployable without deploying a new version of Ambari.  (which your current proposal kind of goes against.) So they should be in fact separate entities that exist outside an ambari install.  Perhaps you don't need to push this upstream but instead add a new structure to this project and host all the code changes here as a management pack?  (They're just supposed to be tarballs that you can throw into other ambari's, not tied to a release.)

I know there are other management packs included with Ambari already so their is totally a precedent set in terms of what other have done.  I still believe it goes against the spirit of the whole thing.  If they are to be shipped with ambari then it's supposed to be a stack and not a management pack.  (I have to say I prefer Mpacks as at this time it seems they're cleaner/self contained.  So if that's why you did it I get it, still feel like it should be a releasable artifact.)

I mean all this to say "this looks amazing"  I want it.  Can I have it without having to download a patched Ambari?  (I totally will if it comes to that.  Just again kind of feels against the intent of what a mpack is.)  I mean I guess I can fork the code and host it separately but I'd rather keep things together.

Also I totally want to see more services included and I"m totally willing to help.  Like for instances writing up how to make this work.

@mattAndruff  Thanks for your comments and it's really appreciated to see more services included in this mpack from your contribution.
In my understanding, you want to get this mapck source code instead of downloading the whole patched Ambari, right? 
I post the mapck source code:  https://github.com/guyuqi/bigtop-mpack 
Please feel free to fork the code above.  Thanks again.

>>_Perhaps you don't need to push this upstream but instead add a new structure to this project and host all the code changes here as a management pack? (They're just supposed to be tarballs that you can throw into other ambari's, not tied to a release.)

@mattAndruff      Does the Mpack tarballs you mentioned aboved look like `xxx-mpack-1.0.0.0-xxx-ambari-mpack.tar.gz` which would be built by `mvn clean package -DskipTests` under the path of `contrib/management-packs/xxx-mpack` ?

>> _If they are to be shipped with ambari then it's supposed to be a stack and not a management pack._ 
>> _So they should be in fact separate entities that exist outside an ambari install._

This Bigtop-mapck is located in ambari `contrib/management-packs/` where some other Mpacks are.
I found that neither the ODPI-mpack nor this Bigtop-Mpack would work properly on all Ambari verision which supports mpack feature.  
What you mean is that the Mpack should be packed as a tarball and could work properly on any version of Ambari, right?  The Mpack should not depend on a specific version of Ambari.
But this Bigtop-Mpack is based on Ambari-2.6.1 and it seems Bigtop-Mpack doesn't work on Ambari-2.7.  Maybe I miss something when developing this Bigtop-mpack.

It would be ideal that it works for all minor point releases. (Everything in the 2.6.x) It's totally fair  that you need to add extra plumbing to support for 2.7.x.   And I'm not expert but it feels like this is reasonable. 

I mean if you could just grab the management pack and use it to install on an existing Ambari-2.6.1 there is huge value.  You could then do a rip and replace of specific services.  Like if you wanted to use the release from bigtop that has "fresher" apache builds than say HDP or CDH.  (Yes, we want to make sure we don't miss dependencies, but I'm saying there would likely be some people that would appreciate the choice.)  

Don't get me wrong, I like that the fresh install from BigTop Ambari could finally deploy something that isn't HDP.  That's great.  I'm just thinking there is a large market of HDP clusters that maybe don't want to switch to cloudera and might consider staying with an open source project like BigTop.

> @mattAndruff Does the Mpack tarballs you mentioned aboved look like xxx-mpack-1.0.0.0-xxx-ambari-mpack.tar.gz which would be built by mvn clean package -DskipTests under the path of contrib/management-packs/xxx-mpack ?

Yes, this is what I wanted.  (edit: tested and it worked)
Cloned https://github.com/guyuqi/bigtop-mpack
`cd /bigtop-mpack/bgtp-ambari-mpack/target`
`mvn clean package -DskipTests `

OK, I'll install this on Amazon and write it up.  
Post it here for big top
Post it on Ambari wiki.
Then do feature parity with existing HDP install, and see what else I can do to help contribute.  (If any features are missing start adding them)
@evans-ye As @iwasakims pointed out, `gnupg` instead of `gpg` in setup-env-debian.sh seems to work on Ubuntu 16.04 in addition to Debian 9. Otherwise LGTM!
+1, thank you for closing the vote @guyuqi!
Thanks @guyuqi @sekikn .

Hey guys. Sorry I got lost while following your discussion. Anyhow I see a health discussion going on for the Ambari Bigtop "integration". Could you summarize the discussion for the actino items of this PR? Thanks!

>If we still put ruby-installation into Bigtop_toolchain, it would override the ruby package already provided by distros.
>So both remove ruby compiling and ruby installation from Bigtop_toolchain.
>
>So just install ruby in the phase of build do-component-build.

What's the different between *ruby-installation into Bigtop_toolchain* and *install ruby in the phase of build do-component-build*? Isn't both of them lead to the same result?
Sorry. My bad. Let me work on a fix. Thanks for discovering the bug and the suggestion @iwasakims @sekikn .

Although I believe they're is more work to complete additional features and
documentation it should not block this PR.  (I will try and find the
ticketing system and add the work there.)

Next week i'll also test it out and look for feature parity with other
systems like HDP.  (That is also outside the scope of this PR in my opinion)

Action required:

1) Decision on how to store the MPack.  I was suggesting it should be an
artifact/code base that is part of this project with it's own folder.  I
have nothing against it being part of Ambari as well, but it's my opinion
that it should have it's own code repo in bigtop.  I don't see Ambari
continuing to maintain a BigTop MPack.  This is my opinion and would
happily discuss alternatives if there are differing opinions.  I stand by
the fact that this MPack could be used in "existing installs" and therefore
doesn't belong bundled into an Ambari install.


On Fri, May 15, 2020 at 2:11 PM Evans Ye <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Hey guys. Sorry I got lost while following your discussion. Anyhow I see a
> health discussion going on for the Ambari Bigtop "integration". Could you
> summarize the discussion for the actino items of this PR? Thanks!
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/bigtop/pull/555#issuecomment-629404601>, or
> unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGNDC7C6HAYQSZUFTWCFI2TRRWAUZANCNFSM4JGDLS6A>
> .
>

>> What's the different between ruby-installation into Bigtop_toolchain and install ruby in the phase of build do-component-build? Isn't both of them lead to the same result?

1. Install ruby-2.4.0 in Bigtop_toolchain:  
Bigtop_toolchain is the common facility for all components in Bigtop. 
It would override the ruby package already installed by distros. 
If put ruby-2.4.0 in Bigtop_toolchain, ruby-2.4.0 is used for both build-time and runtime.
Maybe there are some dependency issues for other components which is concened from cos ([comments](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BIGTOP-3346?focusedCommentId=17093457&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-17093457)).

2.  Install ruby-2.4.0 in do-component-build: 
It's just for logstash build-time.
For logstash runtime, we could leverage the ruby (2.4+ ) provided by distros.

3. Why do we not leverage the ruby provided by distro but install ruby-2.4.0 in do-component-build to build logstash?
When `rake bootstrap` in the phase of build, some dependency packages like `minitar-0.5.4` would not be installed properly by leveraged ruby 2.4+ (2.4.10 or 2.5.8).
For runtime, logstash would work properly on every version of ruby 2.4.0+.
The PR was updated.

OK this didn't run on 2.6.0 on Amazon linux 2.  
```
19 May 2020 20:14:47,870  WARN [ambari-client-thread-21] AmbariMetaInfo:1448 - Could not make a stack VDF for BGTP-1.0: javax.xml.bind.MarshalException
 - with linked exception:
[org.xml.sax.SAXParseException; lineNumber: 0; columnNumber: 0; cvc-enumeration-valid: Value 'fedora26' is not facet-valid with respect to enumeration '[redhat6, redhat7, redhat-ppc6, redhat-ppc7, debian6, debian7, ubuntu12, ubuntu14, ubuntu16, suse11, suse12]'. It must be a value from the enumeration.]
19 May 2020 20:14:47,871  INFO [ambari-client-thread-21] AmbariMetaInfo:1456 - Stack BigInsights-4.2.5 is not active, skipping VDF
19 May 2020 20:14:47,871  INFO [ambari-client-thread-21] AmbariMetaInfo:1456 - Stack Bigtop-2.1 is not active, skipping VDF
```
I'll try again tomorrow with Centos.  see if I have better luck.  (I checked it is supported by Ambari on 2.6.0 only.)

@sekikn I got the following error on provisioning with the patch and `enable_local_repo = true`. `yum-config-manager` seems to be replaced by `yum config-manager` on CentOS 8.
```
sudo: yum-config-manager: command not found
```

After I fixed the yum-config-manager part, I got the another error. Installing `rng-tools` seemed to be failed.
```
Failed to download metadata for repo 'AppStream'
Error: Failed to download metadata for repo 'AppStream'
sed: can't read /usr/lib/systemd/system/rngd.service: No such file or directory
Failed to start rngd.service: Unit rngd.service not found.
```
@sekikn Sorry, the cause of the error was that I did not update docker image by build.sh.
Hmm... starting services by `systemctl` does not work in docker container. Since it works outside container, I'm suspecting issue like https://github.com/docker/for-linux/issues/835.

adding /sys/fs/cgroup to volumes worked for me to fix the `systemctl` issue.
```
diff --git a/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml b/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml
index cee849e9..b3bb1a42 100644
--- a/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml
+++ b/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml
@@ -24,3 +24,4 @@ bigtop:
     - ./config/hiera.yaml:/etc/puppet/hiera.yaml
     - ./config/hieradata:/etc/puppet/hieradata
     - ./config/hosts:/etc/hosts
+    - /sys/fs/cgroup:/sys/fs/cgroup:ro
```
Great, will try it locally. Thanks!
@iwasakims Thanks! Will address your comments.

> If put ruby-2.4.0 in Bigtop_toolchain, ruby-2.4.0 is used for both build-time and runtime.

This is not correct. If put ruby-2.4.0 in bigtop_toolchain, It's used in build time only. Why you say so?

> Install ruby-2.4.0 in do-component-build:
> It's just for logstash build-time.

Even though we do this. We should remove the ruby installation after logstash is built. Otherwise the build env is tainted. Can we guarantee a clean removal?

I don't think dynamic dependency installation is a good way to go. We should make build env consistent. The way we do it is bigtop toolchain.

> adding /sys/fs/cgroup to volumes worked for me to fix the `systemctl` issue.
> 
> ```
> diff --git a/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml b/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml
> index cee849e9..b3bb1a42 100644
> --- a/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml
> +++ b/provisioner/docker/docker-compose.yml
> @@ -24,3 +24,4 @@ bigtop:
>      - ./config/hiera.yaml:/etc/puppet/hiera.yaml
>      - ./config/hieradata:/etc/puppet/hieradata
>      - ./config/hosts:/etc/hosts
> +    - /sys/fs/cgroup:/sys/fs/cgroup:ro
> ```

@iwasakims Can you share some technical reference to this. Thanks!

> Can you share some technical reference to this. 

@evans-ye The background is similar to [BIGTOP-3302](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BIGTOP-3302). systemd added check to see if service process belongs to the service as a fix for [CVE-2018-16888](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2018-16888). The check uses cgroups.
* https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/6632
* https://github.com/systemd/systemd/pull/7816

If cgroups info is not available, init script fails with following message, indicating failure of checking added by the https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/6632.
```
May 21 11:53:07 2eef6a902086 zookeeper-server[2620]: Starting zookeeper ... STARTED
May 21 11:53:07 2eef6a902086 runuser[2665]: pam_unix(runuser:session): session closed for user zookeeper
May 21 11:53:07 2eef6a902086 systemd[1]: zookeeper-server.service: New main PID 2714 does not belong to service, and PID file is not owned by root. Refusing.
```
Thanks @iwasakims, I also confirmed your fix worked well. I updated the PR.

>>_This is not correct. If put ruby-2.4.0 in bigtop_toolchain, It's used in build time only. Why you say so?_

Maybe I have misunderstanding here and please correct me:
In docker build scripts of bigtop-slaves:  https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/master/docker/bigtop-slaves/build.sh#L45-L79
The ruby-2.4.0 as the part of `bigtop_toolchain` would be contained in the docker images like` bigtop/slaves :xxx-ubuntu-18.04.
`
If we run the logstash against in this docker image,  ruby-2.4.0 would override the ruby-2.5 provided by Ubuntu-18.04.


>>_I don't think dynamic dependency installation is a good way to go. We should make build env consistent. The way we do it is bigtop toolchain._

For the reason above and the disscussion in #632, ruby would not be installed in bigtop_toolchain. 
I agree with you that dynamic dependency installation in `do-component-build` is not an elegant solution, but it may be a feasible approach just for this case.  Surely I would like to remove the ruby installation after logstash is built by [rvm remove](https://rvm.io/rubies/removing).

>The ruby-2.4.0 as the part of bigtop_toolchain would be contained in the docker images like bigtop/slaves :xxx-ubuntu-18.04.
>If we run the logstash against in this docker image, ruby-2.4.0 would override the ruby-2.5 provided by Ubuntu-18.04.

bigtop/slaves is used for package building. bigtop/puppet is used for deployment. bigtop/slaves is based on bigtop/puppet so that it's able to execute puppet(for running bigtop toolchain).

> For the reason above and the discussion in #632, ruby would not be installed in bigtop_toolchain.

I'd like to clarify the understanding of #632 with you. CMIIW, what I get from #632 is we don't need to compile ruby 2.4 on our own if we just focus on the newer Distros. They've ruby 2.4 provided already. Therefore I think we can just install Distro. provided ruby by bigtop toolchain. What's the reason that we can't do Package {"ruby"}  directly in bigtop toolchain?

>Surely I would like to remove the ruby installation after logstash is built by rvm remove.

Thanks. If we have to do it in do-component-build anyway. I'm OK with it if removal is implemented.

> 1) Decision on how to store the MPack.  I was suggesting it should be an
artifact/code base that is part of this project with it's own folder.  I
have nothing against it being part of Ambari as well, but it's my opinion
that it should have it's own code repo in bigtop.  I don't see Ambari
continuing to maintain a BigTop MPack.  This is my opinion and would
happily discuss alternatives if there are differing opinions.  I stand by
the fact that this MPack could be used in "existing installs" and therefore
doesn't belong bundled into an Ambari install.

Thanks @mattAndruff for the summary.
Technically speaking I think put Bigtop MPack in Ambari is the suitable way which increase the touch point we have to the users. The best result for this way is to have bigtop MPack upstream to Amabari. However this might be a strategic thing.
Alternatively, we do it in Bigtop. Now we've it built-in with Bigtop built Ambari packages. You're suggesting to make it isolated for direct consume. May I know more about the use case and the structure/layout you're proposing. Ex: another git repo or a top-level dir or somewhere else.
`./gradlew hadoop-rpm` worked on both CentOS 8 and CentOS 7. While CentOS 7 does not support _build_id_links, defining unused macros should be harmless.

>>What's the reason that we can't do Package {"ruby"} directly in bigtop toolchain?

Because some dependency packages like minitar-0.5.4 would **not** be installed properly by leveraged ruby 2.4+ (2.4.10 or 2.5.8), it means ruby-2.4.0 is only one version that was verified to **build** logstash on all platform and Distros. 
It may be not guaranteed that the version of ruby installed by `Package {"ruby"}` is **2.4.0** , for ruby-2.4.0 package may be not available for all Distros in different platforms(arm/x86/ppc).
For runtime, logstash would work properly on every version of ruby 2.4.0+.

>>Thanks. If we have to do it in do-component-build anyway. I'm OK with it if removal is implemented.

I'll update it, thanks @evans-ye
Thanks! Merged into master.
+1, I also confirmed that Hadoop was successfully built and installed on CentOS 7 and 8 with this PR. Thanks!

Well, since this is a management pack it can be deployed to any Ambari.  This would be super helpful for people that want:

1. Want to use BigTop MPack to install a specific build.  Say you are on spark 2.2 and want to be on spark 2.4 for a fix.  The BigTop MPack and its ability to build repos gives you that option.
2. You have an existing installation and want to migrat off of HDP and onto BigTop.  I'm not sure of the market but there must be some people using 100% free HDP and want to keep getting updates now that HDP is not going to be updated.
I'd definitely suggest this is maintained in a top level dir.  (Not just as a patch) That way people can contribute to it.  (like me)

> minitar-0.5.4 would not be installed properly by leveraged ruby 2.4+ (2.4.10 or 2.5.8)

OK, so I'm very much confused by this. No other minor version is acceptable? What kind of problem it would be to prevent minitar-0.5.4 to install with ruby 2.4+? Can we use different version of minicar? I'm very curious about it since I feel there's something unprofessional happening there...

Anyhow, the argument is for building Logstash, exactly version of ruby = 2.4.0 is required. If that's the constrain then I've no choice to agree with the solution you proposed.

I personally think that's good. To proceed I suggest to put this to discussion/vote on bigtop mailing list so that we make the decision with community concensus. 

@guyuqi are we on the same page for this?

For people can contribute to Mpack, I absolutely agree to put mpack into a dir not just as a patch. 
BTW, may I ask where `top level dir`  is?
